ygData.subject: Random Initialisation
ygData.msgSnippet: This is an idea that follows from the discussion on networks with arbitrary complexity possibly being useful as starting points for biological brains. Very

Subject: Random Initialisation
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770077; y=N21NQvnYDP9qKhG5EuHnNjMZmYPjEVL5emv2DiNSfbUn9jPvF1Wl

This is an idea that follows from the discussion on networks with
arbitrary complexity possibly being useful as starting points for
biological brains.

Very simply I'm considering experimenting with random initial
populations of varying sizes & complexities (and perhaps schemes for
generating random connections/nodes) and then running NEAT in pruning
mode first before complexifying. The pruning potentially gets you back
to a population of low complexity networks that have more diversity
than we normally start with. The motivation is that this might help in
the "you can't get there from here" problem of being stuck in some
sub-space of the fitness landscape. Starting with no nodes or even no
connections puts the whole population in one part of the sub-space
from which it might struggle to escape - this is especially true if
you factor neywork size into the fitness function which is an idea
I've bounced around before.

Further to this I'm also thinking about network mutations that do more
than the current 'micro' mutations we all tend to use (add/delete
connection or weight change). We sort of do something like this
already in that a weight change mutation can be for a single
connection or applied to all or some proportion of connections. In
addition I propose that connection addition/deletion mutations that
perform multiple mutations as one operation might have beneficial
effects over and above the normal approach of aggregating positive
mutations over time and through crossover. Again the motivation is in
helping NEAT to make slightly bolder jumps into new regions of the
fitness space (but not too bold).

One can also invisage having a very large number of new connections as
part of a single mutation, but that have very low connection weights
such that they are almost functionally redundant (but not entirely).
The beneficial connections may 'grow' in strength and the useless ones
would get eliminated during pruning.

Colin
